revision.text:
{{About|the art exhibition|the music label|Hell, etc. (label)}} '''Hell, etc.''' was [[Marilyn Manson]]'s third [[art exhibition]], held in [[Athens]], [[Greece]]. The exhibition was opened to the public from April 28, 2010 until May 2, 2010. Manson's more recent artworks and newly revealed pieces, of the time, were displayed.
==Background== The art exhibition was scheduled to run from April 21, 2010, until April 25, 2010, however due to the volcanic ash cloud was postponed to begin on April 28, 2010, and be open from that date until May 2, 2010. This was correctly reported by [http://new.e-go.gr/exodos/article.asp?catid=6472&subid=2&pubid=7812548 E-Go.Gr].<ref>[http://www.providermodule.com/marilyn_manson_news.php?fn_mode=fullnews&fn_id=94 E-Go.Gr update on Hell, etc. by Marilyn Manson. Art exhibition postponed due volcanic ash.]</ref>
The exhibition was held at the Athenian Cultural Centre. The exhibition opened at 10:00 daily and was open until 22:00. Flash photography was prohibited inside the exhibition, as the watercolor paintings were extremely sensitive to the [[Flash (photography)|flash]].<ref>[http://www.mansonwiki.com/wiki/Hell,_etc._(exhibition) Information of the Hell, etc. art exhibition.]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://marilynmanson.com/ Official Marilyn Manson website]
{{Marilyn Manson}} [[Category:Art exhibitions]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Holly Marie Combs | image = WW Chicago 2012 - Holly-Marie Combs 01 (7785647308).jpg | image_size = | caption = Combs at the [[London Film and Comic Con]]vention in July 2012 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1973|12|3|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[San Diego, California]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[Professional Children's School]] | occupation = [[Actress]]{{*}}[[television producer]] | years_active = 1985–present | known_for = [[Piper Halliwell]] on ''[[Charmed]]'' | spouse = {{unbulleted list|{{marriage|Bryan Travis Smith|1993|1997}}|{{marriage|David Donoho|2004|2011}}}} | children = 3 }} '''Holly Marie Combs''' (born December 3, 1973){{cite web|url=http://movies.msn.com/celebrities/celebrity-biography/holly-marie-combs|title=Holly Marie Combs: Biography|publisher=MSN Movies|accessdate=July 16, 2012}} is an American actress and television producer. She is known for her roles as Kimberly Brock in the [[CBS]] series ''[[Picket Fences]]'' (1992–1996), [[Piper Halliwell]] in [[The WB]] series ''[[Charmed]]'' (1998–2006) and [[Ella Montgomery]] in the [[Freeform (TV channel)|Freeform]] series ''[[Pretty Little Liars]]'' (2010–2017). ==Early life== Combs was born in [[San Diego, California]] and has described herself as being of [[Irish people|Irish]] descent.{{cite news|title=Holly Charms Hollywood|url=http://charmed-net.de/en/webtv/show_article.asp?id=47|work=Cosmopolitan|date=December 2000|author=Kizis, Deanna|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528234106/http://charmed-net.de/en/webtv/show_article.asp?id=47|archivedate=May 28, 2008|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=Holly Marie Combs Dishes on Life With Her Boys|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2008/09/17/holly-marie-com|work=People|date=September 17, 2008}} At the time of her birth, her mother, Lauralei Combs (née Berckhem), was 16 years old, and her father was 17. Combs's biological parents married, but the two split up after two years,{{cite web|url=http://www.askmen.com/women/actress_150/176_holly_marie_combs.html |title=Profile: Holly Marie Combs|website= askmen.com|access-date= January 7, 2015}} feeling they were too young to make a marriage work. While Combs was learning to walk, she fell and hit her head on a marble table, resulting in a noticeable 'split' at the top of her right eyebrow. She lived in many different homes with her mother, near the beach in San Diego, often having very little privacy, while her mother attempted to pursue an acting career.{{cite web|url= http://www.tv.com/people/holly-marie-combs|title=People: Holly Marie Combs|website=tv.com|accessdate=September 15, 2013}} When Combs was 7, she and her mother moved to [[New York City]] where she spent most of her growing years. Combs was 12 when her mother married her stepfather. In New York City, Combs attended Beekman Hill Elementary and then the [[Professional Children's School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pcs-nyc.org/page.cfm?page=1302}} In an interview when she was in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]], for [[Supanova Expo]], she said that she was a certified [[scuba diver]] at 13.{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/video/watch/31914652/charmed-stars/?cmp=st&cmp=st|title=Charmed stars|website=Yahoo! News}} ==Career== ===Early work: 1988–1997=== [[File:Holly Marie Combs.jpg|thumb|upright|Combs at the [[43rd Primetime Emmy Awards|1993 Emmy Awards]]]] When she was 14 years old, Combs landed her first major role in ''[[Sweet Hearts Dance]]'' (1988), a [[comedy drama]] film directed by [[Robert Greenwald]]. She played Debs Boon, the daughter of Wiley Boon (played by [[Don Johnson]]) and Sandra Boon (played by [[Susan Sarandon]]).{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/person/holly-marie-combs/biography.html|title=Holly Marie Combs Biography|work=Yahoo! Movies|publisher=Yahoo! Inc|accessdate=July 15, 2012}} Her next major role was in [[Oliver Stone]]'s ''[[Born on the Fourth of July (film)|Born on the Fourth of July]]'' (1989), a film adaptation of the best selling [[autobiography]] of the [[Born on the Fourth of July|same name]] by [[Vietnam War]] veteran [[Ron Kovic]]. Combs portrayed Jenny in the film, which also starred [[Tom Cruise]]. Her other roles included Helena in the 1989 [[anthology film]] ''[[New York Stories]]'', and Kim Fields in [[Hal Hartley]]'s ''[[Simple Men]]'' (1992). Also in 1992, Combs made an appearance in [[Temístocles López]]'s ''[[Chain of Desire]]'' as Diana, and in the [[slasher film]] ''[[Dr. Giggles]]'', in which she played Jennifer Campbell, the 19-year-old daughter of Tom Campbell (played by [[Cliff De Young]]) and girlfriend of Max Anderson (played by [[Glenn Quinn]]). Combs's first major breakthrough as an actress came at the age of 18, in the [[CBS]] television series ''[[Picket Fences]]''. She portrayed Kimberly Brock, the daughter of Sheriff Jimmy Brock (played by [[Tom Skerritt]]) and his first wife Lydia for the show's four seasons (1992–96). Jimmy's second wife, Dr. Jill Brock (played by [[Kathy Baker]]), was her stepmother. Combs auditioned for the role in New York. The casting agent told her that she wasn't right for the part because she "didn't have a big enough heart." Combs retorted, "If you're looking for someone with a big heart, what the hell are you doing in New York?". She was later called back and offered the job. Combs won a [[Young Artist Award]] for her performance on the show. During 1996, Combs starred as Sophie DiMatteo in ''[[Sins of Silence]]'', a drama/horror [[television film]] directed by [[Sam Pillsbury]]. The following year, Combs portrayed real-life convicted murderer [[Diane Zamora]] in the television film ''[[Swearing Allegiance|Love's Deadly Triangle: The Texas Cadet Murder]]'', and appeared in the fact-based drama film ''[[Daughters (1997 TV film)|Daughters]]'' as Alex Morell, one of the two daughters of a murdered heiress. === Later work: 1998–present === In 1998, Combs landed a lead role in [[The WB]] television series ''[[Charmed]]'', in which she portrayed [[Piper Halliwell]], the middle of three sisters who are [[witch]]es. Following [[Shannen Doherty]]'s departure after [[Charmed (season 3)|season three]] (2000–01), Combs's character became the eldest sister for the remaining five seasons of the show. Combs also became a producer for ''Charmed'' from [[Charmed (season 5)|season five]] onwards.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0158552/combined|title=Charmed – Full Cast and Crew|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=June 21, 2006}} The series ended its eight-season run on May 21, 2006. In 2007 and 2008, [[AOL]] named Combs's character Piper the third greatest witch in television history. Combs was the only cast member to appear in every episode of the series, including the original unaired pilot. During ''Charmed'', Combs made a cameo appearance in [[Steven Soderbergh]]'s ''[[Ocean's Eleven]]'' (2001), and starred opposite [[Charisma Carpenter]] in the [[romantic comedy]] film ''[[See Jane Date]]'' (2003), portraying the role of "a struggling actress whose career benefits from an affair with an A-list actor." In 2007, she starred in the [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] television film ''Point of Entry'' (also titled ''Panic Button'') as Kathy Alden, a wife and mother of a single child whose family moves to a "beautiful and supposedly secure gated community after she's the victim of a violent house break-in."{{cite web|url=http://tvjots.com/panic-button-pipers-no-longer-charmed/|title=Panic Button: Piper's No Longer Charmed in Dull 'Suspense' Yarn|publisher=Tvjots.com|date=November 3, 2007|accessdate=July 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125041523/http://tvjots.com/panic-button-pipers-no-longer-charmed/|archivedate=January 25, 2012|df=mdy-all}} The following year, Combs signed a contract with Lifetime to produce and star in a series ''[[Mistresses (U.S. TV series)|Mistresses]]'', based on the [[Mistresses (UK TV series)|British series of the same name]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/Charmed-Holly-Lifetimes-14813.aspx|title=Charmed Holly Is One of Lifetime's Mistresses|publisher=Tvguide.com|date=July 9, 2008|accessdate=July 15, 2012}} However, that version of the show never made it to air. ([[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] later made a version featuring Combs's former ''Charmed'' co-star [[Alyssa Milano]].) In 2010, Combs was cast in the [[Freeform (TV channel)|Freeform]] series ''[[Pretty Little Liars]]'' as Ella Montgomery, the mother of one of the main characters, [[Aria Montgomery]] (played by [[Lucy Hale]]).{{cite web|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2010/04/10/holly-marie-combs-pretty-little-liars/|title=Exclusive: Holly Marie Combs joins 'Pretty Little Liars'|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|date=April 10, 2010|accessdate=July 15, 2012}} Combs was a series regular for the first three seasons, but became credited as a special guest star from season four onwards. ''Pretty Little Liars'' ended after seven seasons, and Combs returned for the show's final episode on June 27, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2016/10/15/pretty-little-liars-series-finale-photos-moms-final-scene-video/|title=Pretty Little Liars Series Finale Photos: The Moms Say Goodbye to Rosewood|last=Swift|first=Andy|publisher=[[TVLine]]|date=October 15, 2016|accessdate=September 13, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/pretty-liars-series-finale-recap-ad-married-pregnant/story?id=48288481|title='Pretty Little Liars' series finale recap: Who is AD, who got married, who's pregnant|last=Valiente|first=Alexa|work=[[ABC News]]|date=June 27, 2017|accessdate=September 13, 2017}} Combs and Doherty starred in their own road trip reality show ''Off the Map with Shannen & Holly'', which premiered on [[Great American Country]] on January 2, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/07/shannen-doherty-holly-marie-combs-off-the-map-series-great-american-country|title=Shannen Doherty & Holly Marie Combs Go 'Off The Map' On Great American Country|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[PMC (company)|PMC]]|date=July 24, 2014|accessdate=July 26, 2014}}{{cite web|title='Off the Map with Shannen & Holly' Premieres on January 2|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2014/12/29/off-the-map-with-shannen-holly-premieres-january-2|last=Spining|first=Molly|date=December 29, 2014|publisher=[[Great American Country]]|accessdate=January 4, 2015}} The six-episode series followed the pair traveling across southeastern United States, with stops in [[Kentucky]], [[Tennessee]], [[Mississippi]], [[Alabama]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and [[Florida]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/shannen-doherty-holly-marie-combs-reality-show-off-map-1084933.aspx|title=Charmed's Shannen Doherty and Holly Marie Combs Reunite for Reality Show|last=Gennis|first=Sadie|work=[[TV Guide]]|date=July 25, 2014|accessdate=July 26, 2014}} Viewers were able to vote on activities Doherty and Combs would partake in at each destination on Great American Country's official website. In January 2016, Combs starred in the [[Hallmark Channel]] television film ''Love's Complicated'', playing the lead role of Leah Townsend, a big city novel writer and senator's daughter who is "known for being a people pleaser."{{cite web|url=https://www.inquisitr.com/2690837/loves-complicated-hallmark-teaches-conflict-resolution-for-doormats-in-romantic-movie-starring-holly-marie-combs-ben-bass/|title='Love's Complicated': Hallmark teaches conflict for doormats in romantic movie, starring Holly Marie Combs, Ben Bass|last=Reyes|first=Traciy|work=[[Inquisitr]]|date=January 8, 2016|accessdate=September 13, 2017}} == Personal life == In 1993, Combs married actor Bryan Travis Smith; they divorced in 1997.{{cite news|title=Charmed star Holly Marie Combs files for divorce from second husband David Donoho|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2060523/Charmed-star-Holly-Marie-Combs-files-divorce-second-husband-David-Donoho.html|work=People Magazine|date=November 11, 2011}} On February 14, 2004, she married her long-time boyfriend and the former ''Charmed'' key-grip David Donoho. They are the parents of three sons: Finley Arthur Donoho (born April 26, 2004), Riley Edward Donoho (born October 26, 2006), and Kelley James Donoho (born May 26, 2009), all born by [[Caesarian section]] (Kelley was an emergency C-section). Combs kept her third pregnancy a secret because it was high risk, with a delivery at 35 weeks.{{cite web|url=http://celebrity-babies.com/2009/06/05/holly-marie-combs-welcomes-son-kelley-james/|title=Holly Marie Combs Welcomes Son Kelley James|website=Celebrity Babies}} In November 2011, she filed for divorce from Donoho, citing irreconcilable differences.{{cite news|title=Holly Marie Combs No Longer Bewitched by Husband, Files for Divorce|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/holly_marie_combs_no_longer_bewitched/274740|author=Serpe, Gina|date=November 11, 2011|work=[[E!]]|accessdate=November 11, 2011}} On September 3, 2017, Combs announced on her official [[Instagram]] account her engagement to her boyfriend Mike, sharing a picture of an marquise-cut diamond ring.{{cite news|url=http://people.com/tv/charmed-star-holly-marie-combs-is-engaged-see-her-gorgeous-ring/|title=Charmed Star Holly Marie Combs Is Engaged! See Her Gorgeous Ring|last=Corriston|first=Michele|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=September 4, 2017|accessdate=September 14, 2017}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1985 | ''[[Walls of Glass]]'' | Abby Hall | Classmate |- | 1988 | ''[[Sweet Hearts Dance]]'' | Dens Boon | |- | rowspan=2| 1989 | ''[[New York Stories]]'' | Helena | Costume Party Girl |- | ''[[Born on the Fourth of July (film)|Born on the Fourth of July]]'' | Jenny Turner | |- | 1991 | ''Nobody Can Hear You Scream'' | Melinda Ashwood | |- | rowspan=3|1992 | ''[[Simple Men]]'' | Kim Fields | |- | ''[[Dr. Giggles]]'' | Jennifer Campbell | Lead role |- | ''[[Chain of Desire]]'' | Diana Richards | |- | rowspan=2|1995 | ''[[A Reason to Believe]]'' | Sharon Digby | Independent movie |- | ''Evil in the Basement'' | Karen Ford | |- | 2001 | ''[[Ocean's Eleven]]'' | Herself | Cameo |} === Television === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Online]]|date=July 3, 2011|accessdate=September 6, 2014}} |- | 2016 | ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' | Top 10 Greatest Witches of All Time (Piper Halliwell) | {{won|6th}} |{{cite web|url=http://m.huffpost.com/uk/entry/8417646|title=The Top 10 Greatest Witches of All Time|last=Ellis|first=Phillip|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=October 30, 2016|accessdate=May 20, 2017}} |- |} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Holly Marie Combs}} * {{IMDb name|0001061|Holly Marie Combs}} * [http://www.hollymcombs.com/ Official website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Combs, Holly Marie}} [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Actresses from New York City]] [[Category:Actresses from San Diego]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American child actresses]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American soap opera actresses]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:Women television producers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Television producers from California]] [[Category:Television producers from New York City]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:21st-century American actresses]]

'''Hymnology''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ὕμνος ''hymnos'', "song of praise" and -λογία ''-logia'', "study of") is the [[scholar]]ly study of [[religious]] [[song]], or the [[hymn]], in its many aspects, with particular focus on [[choir|choral]] and [[Wiktionary:congregation|congregational]] song. It may be more or less clearly distinguished from ''[[Hymn|hymnody]]'', the creation and practice of such song. Hymnologists, such as [[Erik Routley]], may study the history and origins of hymns and of traditions of sung worship, the biographies of the women and men who have written hymns that have passed into choral or congregational use, the interrelationships between text and tune, the historical processes, both folk and redactional, that have changed hymn texts and [[hymn tune]]s over time, and the sociopolitical, theological and aesthetic arguments concerning various styles of sung worship.
Hymnology is sometimes more strictly construed, as in ''[[A Dictionary of Hymnology]]'',<ref>John Julian, ed., (1902/1985), ''A Dictionary of Hymnology'', Grand Rapids, MI: Kregel.</ref> edited by [[John D. Julian]], which concerns itself very largely with the history, textual changes, and translations of hymns, and with the biographies of [[hymnographer]]s, and very little with the [[Metre (poetry)|poetic metres]] of these hymns, or with the [[hymn tune]]s to which these are sung.
==See also== *[[Foot (prosody)]] *[[Hymn tune]] *[[Hymnal]] *[[Hymn Society in the United States and Canada]] *[[Hymn Society of Great Britain and Ireland]] *[[Hymnographer]] *[[Hymns and hymn tunes]] *[[Metre (hymn)]] *[[Metre (poetry)]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{commonscat}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=aBDpAAAAIAAJ ''A Dictionary of Hymnology''] on Google Books. *[http://www.hymnsocietygbi.org.uk/ The Hymn Society of Great Britain and Ireland] *[http://www.thehymnsociety.org/ The Hymn Society in the United States and Canada] *[http://www.iah.unibe.ch/ Internationale Arbeitsgemeinschaft für Hymnologie] (in German). *[http://www.oberlin.edu/library/DAH.html Dictionary of American Hymnology at Oberlin College] *[http://www.smithcreekmusic.com/Hymnology/Historical.Periods.html A list of periods, areas and genres of hymnody] *[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07596a.htm Catholic Encyclopedia]

page.title: I Spit on Your Grave III: Vengeance Is Mine

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = I Spit on Your Grave III:
Vengence Is Mine | image = I Spit on Your Grave 3 poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = R.D. Braunstein | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Lisa M. Hansen]] * [[Paul Hertzberg]] }} | writer = Daniel Gilboy | based on = | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Sarah Butler]] * [[Jennifer Landon]] * [[Doug McKeon]] * [[Gabriel Hogan]] * [[Harley Jane Kozak]] * [[Michelle Hurd]] }} | music = [[Edwin Wendler]] | cinematography = Richard J. Vialet | editing = Ana Florit | studio = [[CineTel Films]] | distributor = [[Anchor Bay Films]] | released = {{film date|2015|10|23|US}} | runtime = 91 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $144,420 {{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&country=R2&wk=2015W42&id=_fISPITONYOURGRAVE01 |title=I Spit On Your Grave: Vengeance is Mine |accessdate=2015-10-01 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo (website)|Box Office Mojo]] | work =[[Anchor Bay Films]]}} }} '''''I Spit on Your Grave III: Vengeance Is Mine''''' is a 2015 American [[Rape and revenge films|rape and revenge]] [[horror film]], directed by R.D. Braunstein from a screenplay by Daniel Gilboy. It is the third installment in the series. [[Sarah Butler]] reprises her role as [[Jennifer Hills]] from the 2010 film ''[[I Spit on Your Grave (2010 film)|I Spit on Your Grave]]''.{{cite web |url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/exclusives/3337017/anchor-bay-acquires-spit-grave-vengeance-mine-exclusive/ |title=I Spit On Your Grave: Vengeance is Mine |accessdate=2015-10-18 |publisher= | work =Bloody Disgusting}} ==Plot== The film follows the life of [[Jennifer Hills]], continuing her story from ''[[I Spit on Your Grave (2010 film)|I Spit on Your Grave]]''. After Jennifer survived her assault and exacted revenge on the men who raped her, she avoided conviction for her killing spree and settled in Los Angeles. She is no longer an aspiring writer and now devotes herself between working as an assault hotline operator and going to group counseling under the assumed name Angela Jitrenka. She is also periodically shown attending personal therapy for her ordeal. Jennifer's scarring experience has left her highly distrustful and defensive towards most men, including her colleague Matthew, who has a seemingly genuine interest in her. While in group counseling, Jennifer develops a bond with one of the girls in the group, Marla, who also does not trust men. The duo began their own personal crusade, by exacting poetic justice for victims of sexual assault. However, just as Jennifer begins to enjoy life, Marla dies under mysterious circumstances and no one is found guilty of her death. She becomes acquainted with Detective McDylan, an investigator to Marla's death who, however, fails to bring justice for Marla nor closure for Jennifer. Distraught and enraged at how the law could not help Marla nor the rape victims in her support group, she decides to get revenge for them. One by one, Jennifer stalks and lures the unpunished rapists to a private place to torture and kill them. Her first victim is Marla's estranged boyfriend and alleged murderer, soon followed by the stepfather of a teenage member of the group. After befriending Oscar, the only male member of the support group who lost his daughter to suicide after a sexual assault, Jennifer tracks down his daughter's rapist. The man manages to overpower her as she tries to attack him, until he is shot dead by the police, whose attention Jennifer had been drawing through her actions. The police take Jennifer in for questioning, revealing their knowledge of her real identity in an attempt to obtain a confession. However Oscar, who had grown sympathetic to Jennifer's cause, walks into the police station after slashing his own arms, and publicly admits to the murders before dying from his wounds. No longer the prime suspect, Jennifer is released but stays under police watch as a person of interest. She has a nervous breakdown, becoming further disillusioned with society and no longer able to discern well-meaning men from sexual predators. Clad in a suggestive red dress in order to bait men, Jennifer leaves her home, evading the police watch. First she unsuccessfully attacks Matthew and scares him away, then she tries to lure a local thug who had been harassing her. As Jennifer is about to kill him, she is shot and arrested by McDylan, who had been trailing her the whole time. It is now revealed Jennifer's personal therapy sessions were part of her mandatory treatment following a two-year sentence for attempted murder, lacking evidence of the murders she actually committed. After completing the final session before her release, Jennifer leaves the doctor's office and switches the "therapist" sign on the door to read "the rapist". She then imagines being attacked by two inmates, who she kills, before killing her therapist who had left the room to stop it, revealing that her fantasies of killing are not over. The film ends as she walks down the hallway smiling. ==Cast== * [[Sarah Butler]] as [[Jennifer Hills]] / Angela Jitrenka * [[Jennifer Landon]] as Marla Finch * [[Doug McKeon]] as Oscar "Koza" Kosca * [[Gabriel Hogan]] as Detective McDylan * [[Harley Jane Kozak]] as Therapist * [[Michelle Hurd]] as Detective Glenn Bolton (in the end credits listed as "Detective Boyle") * Russell Pitts as Matthew * Walter Perez as Chief * [[Karen Strassman]] as Lynne * Christopher Hoffman as Ron ==Box office== The film opened in Russia and Ukraine on October 1, 2015. Russia debuted the movie at the number 11 with a total of $44,021 from 81 screens. Ukraine fared better with a fifth place opening and a weekend total of $18,603 from 48 screens. After a three-week run in Russia and Ukraine, the cumulative totals are $111,089 and $33,331 respectivelyhttp://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/page=&country=00&id=_fISPITONYOURGRAVE01{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/I-Spit-on-Your-Grave-3#tab=summary|title=I Spit on Your Grave 3 (2015) - Financial Information|publisher=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|4530884}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|i_spit_on_your_grave_vengeance_is_mine_2015}} {{I Spit on Your Grave}} {{DEFAULTSORT:I Spit on Your Grave III: Vengeance Is Mine}} [[Category:2015 horror films]] [[Category:2010s crime films]] [[Category:2010s thriller films]] [[Category:2010s sequel films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American horror thriller films]] [[Category:American crime thriller films]] [[Category:American serial killer films]] [[Category:Exploitation films]] [[Category:Feminist films]] [[Category:American sequel films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:CineTel Films films]] [[Category:Rape and revenge films]] [[Category:Films set in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Films about violence against women]] [[Category:Posttraumatic stress disorder in fiction]]

page.title: Illuminare – Centre for the Study of Medieval Art

revision.text:
'''Illuminare – Centre for the Study of Medieval Art''' [[KU Leuven]], is a university-led research and documentation centre. It is situated in the University Library (Ladeuzeplein in Leuven) in the town of [[Leuven]], Belgium and is accessible to both academics and students. The focus on Medieval and Early Modern Art from the Southern Low Countries in a European perspective is facilitated by both research and doctoral projects that are in turn supported by a vast international network of universities, institutions, and museums.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.illuminare.be/|title=Home {{!}} Illuminare|website=www.illuminare.be|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref>
Illuminare conserves and catalogues illuminated manuscripts and carries out art technical research (''Book Heritage Lab'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theo.kuleuven.be/apps/press/bookheritagelab/|title=Book Heritage Lab – KU Leuven|website=theo.kuleuven.be|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vlaamse-erfgoedbibliotheek.be/nieuws/2016/05/3697-opening-book-heritage-lab-ku-leuven|title=Opening Book Heritage Lab - KU Leuven {{!}} Vlaamse Erfgoedbibliotheek|website=www.vlaamse-erfgoedbibliotheek.be|language=nl|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> Recent research and conservation projects performed by the Book Heritage Lab, include the ''[[Codex Eyckensis]]'' (8th century) (2016/18),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.codexeyckensis.be/en/|title=Codex Eyckensis|work=Codex Eyckensis|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.erfgoed-kbs.be/nieuws/oudste-boek-van-belgie-onderzocht|title=Oudste boek van België onderzocht! {{!}} Erfgoed KBS|website=www.erfgoed-kbs.be|language=nl|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kikirpa.be/EN/32/61/news/1376/index.htm?'%20title='Codex%20Eyckensis%20Project|title=kikirpa - News|website=www.kikirpa.be|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> the illuminated manuscripts from the [[Museum Mayer van den Bergh|Mayer van den Bergh]] Museum (2014/19),<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://enrichingheritage.wordpress.com/2015/12/14/looking-past-the-curve-digitising-the-mayer-van-den-bergh-breviary/|title=Looking past the curve. Digitising the Mayer van den Bergh Breviary|date=2015-12-14|work=Enriching Heritage|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en-US}}</ref> the technological study of the Enclosed Gardens of Mechelen (Art Garden, 2016/20)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.esat.kuleuven.be/psi/projects/current/ARTGARDEN|title=ARTGARDEN: Art Technical Research and Preservation of Historical Mixed - Media Ensembles: 'Enclosed Gardens'|website=www.esat.kuleuven.be|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artsflanders.be/news/heritage/city-of-mechelen-restores-enclosed-gardens|title=City of Mechelen restores Enclosed Gardens {{!}} Arts Flanders|website=www.artsflanders.be|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://portablelightdome.wordpress.com/2014/10/08/detailed-imaging-with-the-microdome-of-the-enclosed-gardens-16th-century-mechelen/|title=Detailed imaging with the Microdome of the Enclosed Gardens (16th century), Mechelen|date=2014-10-08|work=Portable Light Dome|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en-US}}</ref> and the [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder|Bruegel]] drawings and prints project (Fingerprint 2016/20).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kbr.be/en/fingerprint|title=FINGERPRINT|date=2016-09-23|work=Royal Library of Belgium|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fingerprintbruegel.wordpress.com/|title=Fingerprint|website=Fingerprint|language=nl-NL|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.esat.kuleuven.be/psi/projects/current/FINGERPRINT|title=FINGERPRINT: Innovative Visual Data Management for Drawings and Prints Collections|website=www.esat.kuleuven.be|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> Equally, Illuminare examines, through an interdisciplinary approach, the iconology of Medieval Art (''Iconology Research Group'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iconologyresearchgroup.org/|title=Barbara Baert {{!}} Illuminare|website=www.iconologyresearchgroup.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> Recent research projects of the Iconology Research Group have been, among others, the study of the phenomenon of the ‘John the Baptist’s head on a platter’ (2012/16),<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baert|first=Barbara|date=2012-06-14|title=Caput Johannis in Disco: {Essay on a Man’s Head}|url=http://www.brill.com/caput-johannis-disco|language=en}}</ref> the study of liturgical objects and their use in Belgian collections (OrnaSacra, 2017/21),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://uclouvain.be/fr/instituts-recherche/incal/ornamenta-sacra.html|title=Projet BRAIN Ornamenta Sacra {{!}} UCLouvain|website=uclouvain.be|language=fr|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> and the examination of the afterlife of the figure of [[Kairos]] (2017/21).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.francquifoundation.be/rapport-test/2016-rapport-jury-barbara-baert/|title=2016 – Rapport Jury Barbara Baert – Fondation Francqui – Stichting|website=www.francquifoundation.be|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> The research centre holds and manages several research archives previously belonging to renowned art historians such as Maurits Smeyers, Bert Cardon, Jan Karel Steppe, Antoine De Schrijver, and Hans Nieuwdorp.
Iluminare organises national and international exhibitions; the most recent exhibitions include, ''In Search of [[Utopia (book)|Utopia]]'' (2016/17, M-Museum of Leuven);<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://utopia.prezly.com/persbericht#|title=PERSBERICHT: Op zoek naar Utopia, de meest spraakmakende tentoonstelling van 2016|access-date=2018-05-14|language=nl-BE}}</ref> ''[[Hieronymus Cock]] - The Renaissance in Print'' (2013, M-Museum of Leuven and Fondation Custodia, Paris);<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artsflanders.be/news/heritage/exhibition-on-hieronymus-cock-travels-to-paris|title=Exhibition on Hieronymus Cock travels to Paris {{!}} Arts Flanders|website=www.artsflanders.be|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://vlaamseprimitieven.vlaamsekunstcollectie.be/en/news/exhibition-hieronymus-cock-the-renaissance-in-print|title=Exhibition Hieronymus Cock - The renaissance in print {{!}} Flemish Primitives|website=vlaamseprimitieven.vlaamsekunstcollectie.be|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> ''Magnificent Middle Ages'' (2013, Museum Plantin-Moretus, Antwerp);<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.museumplantinmoretus.be/en/page/magnificent-middle-ages|title=The Magnificent Middle Ages {{!}} Museum Plantin-Moretus|website=www.museumplantinmoretus.be|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref> ''The Anjou Bible - A Royal Manuscript Revealed'' (2010, M-Museum of Leuven) and ''[[Rogier van der Weyden]] 1400/1464 – Master of Passions'' (2009, M-Museum of Leuven)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.codart.nl/guide/exhibitions/rogier-van-der-weyden-1400-1464-de-passie-van-de-meester/|title=Rogier van der Weyden 1400 {{!}} 1464: de passie van de meester -|work=CODART|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
In addition, the research centre publishes four in-house publications: ''Corpus of Illuminated Manuscripts'', ''Art and Religion'', ''Studies in Iconology'', and ''Iconologies''. Illuminare also produces exhibition catalogues and colloquium proceedings. In 2017, the Royal Flemish Academy for Sciences and the Arts bestowed the whole Illuminare team with the annual Science Communication Prize, in recognition of the exhibition ''In Search of Utopia.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kvab.be/prijzen/jaarprijzen-wetenschapscommunicatie|title=De Jaarprijzen wetenschapscommunicatie {{!}} Koninklijke Vlaamse Academie van België voor Wetenschappen en Kunsten|website=www.kvab.be|language=nl|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Illuminare - Centre for the Study of Medieval Art}} [[Category:Medieval art| ]] [[Category:Art by period of creation]] [[Category:Middle Ages]] [[Category:Types of museum]] [[Category:University museums| ]] [[Category:Educational organisations in Belgium]]

{{for|information on the optics company|IPG Photonics}} {{Infobox publisher | parent = | status = | founded = 1971 | founder = | successor = | country = United States | headquarters = Chicago, Illinois | distribution = | keypeople = | publications = | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | website = {{url|https://www.ipgbook.com/}} }}
'''Independent Publishers Group''' ('''IPG''') is a worldwide [[Distribution (business)|distributor]] for independent general, academic, and professional publishers,<ref>{{cite web|work=Publishers Weekly |title=Book Expo 2018|last=Hartman | first=Elizabeth | date=2018-05-11|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bea/article/76872-bookexpo-2018-around-the-booths.html |accessdate=2018-11-15}}</ref> founded in 1971 to exclusively [[Marketing|market]] titles from independent client [[Publishing|publishers]] to the international book trade. As per other book wholesalers and distributors, IPG combines its client publishers’ books into a single list, comparable to the larger publishing houses. IPG’s distribution services to publishers include [[Warehouse|warehousing]], bill collecting, and sales to the book trade. IPG currently represents about 1,000<ref>http://www.ipgbook.com/publishers-pages-32.php</ref> publishers. They are based in [[Chicago, Illinois]]. IPG distributes publishers based in [[Australia]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[France]], [[Ireland]], [[Switzerland]], [[New Zealand]], [[Israel]], and others.<ref>{{cite web|work=IPG Book |title=The History of IPG| date=2018-05-11|url=https://www.ipgbook.com/history-pages-65.php |accessdate=2018-11-15}}</ref>
==Merger with Chicago Review Press== In 1987, IPG was acquired by '''''[[Chicago Review Press]]''''' (CRP) an independent publisher founded at about the same time as IPG.
==Acquisition of other book distributors== IPG acquired Paul & Company, an 11-year-old distributor of university presses, in 2001. IPG now sells directly to universities.
In 2006, IPG acquired Trafalgar Square Publishing, founded in 1973, which is the distributor of more than 100 publishers from the UK, Australia, New Zealand, China, and Germany, representing more than 20,000 titles. Its roster includes [[HarperCollins]], [[Pan Macmillan]], and [[Penguin Random House]] from the UK and [[Allen and Unwin]] and Penguin Random House from Australia; these publisher's titles are not always issued in US editions.
In 2018, IPG acquired International Specialized Book Services (ISBS), an academic book distributor.<ref>{{Cite web| title = IPG Acquires ISBS| work = PublishersWeekly.com| accessdate = 2018-07-08| url = https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/industry-deals/article/76510-ipg-acquires-isbs.html}}</ref>
In August 2019, IPG acquired the book distributor, [[Midpoint Trade Books]]. Speaking to Publishers Weekly, IPG's CEO, Joe Matthews said that the publishing industry "is consolidating because distribution rewards scale, requires expensive technology, and demands high-level access to customers."<ref>{{cite web|work=Publishers Weekly |title=IPG Acquires Midpoint Trade Books|first=Claire |last=Kirch |date=2018-09-04|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/industry-deals/article/77902-ipg-acquires-midpoint-trade-books.html |accessdate=2018-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work=Shelf Awareness |title=IPG Buys Midpoint Trade Books|date=2018-09-04|url=https://www.shelf-awareness.com/issue.html?issue=3326 |accessdate=2018-11-15}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of book distributors]] *[[Chicago Review Press]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.ipgbook.com}}
[[Category:Book publishing companies based in Illinois]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1971]] [[Category:Book distributors]]

{{Advert|date=July 2014}} [[File:Antique Persian Kerman Rug.jpg|thumb|right|Antique Persian Kerman Rug]] '''Kerman carpets''' (sometimes "Kirman") are one of the traditional classifications of [[Persian carpet]]s. Kerman is both a city and a province located in south central [[Iran]], though the term sometimes describes a type which may have been made elsewhere. Kerman rugs are prized for a wide range of designs, a broad palette, use of natural dyes and fibers, great tensile strength and abrasion resistance, and expert color combinations. Typical manufacturing used an asymmetrical knot on cotton foundation, but rare examples include silk or part silk piles, or silk foundations with wool pile.
==Designs and motifs of the Kerman region== Because of the tremendous demand for rugs produced in Kerman and the complex demographics of this demand, a surprising variety of styles and designs were produced. Some Kerman rugs were woven explicitly for monied buyers from the West, some for local consumers with very different tastes.
Damask Rose is the most popular motif in Kerman rug designs, particularly in "Sabzikar Ravar" and "Gol Sorkhi" (Red Rose) rugs. Other well-known motifs are "Ghab Ghora'ani", "Setooni", "Ghabi", "Kheshti", "Saraam Atiyeh", "Jangali", "Shekargah" and "Lachak-Toranj". Kerman antique carpets often use the Toranj motif border of margins and narrow lines. Floral patterns woven into Kerman carpets in the 19th century are derived from the patterns of Kerman shawls, also made in Kerman at this time.
A distinct variation of Kerman carpets is the Lavar or Ravar Kerman. These carpets were produced in Ravar village next to Kerman city in the northern region and are known particularly for their fine weave and elegant, classically derived design of allover and central medallion formats. Most Ravar or Lavar Kerman carpets include a signature, either that of the weaver or the person for whom the carpet was woven.
[[File:Antique Persian Kerman Rug with Blue Field.jpg|thumb|right|Antique Persian Kerman Rug]]
Vase carpets, a type of Kerman rug distinctive of the 16th and 17th centuries, are characterized by an allover pattern of stylized flowers and oversized palmettes with vases placed throughout the field.
Kerman carpets of the 18th century and later very often use "lattice" patterns, with the central field divided by a lattice design giving many small compartments. A notable illustration is a carpet having belonged to [[William Morris]], now on display at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Carpet|work=V&A|url=http://images.vam.ac.uk/item/O98834/carpet/|accessdate=January 2, 2011}}</ref> Later all sorts of designs were made in Kerman, including large figurative ones. The [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in London has a carpet of 1909 with a design copying a painting by the 18th century French artist [[Antoine Watteau]].<ref>[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O75721/carpet/ V&A Watteau Kirman carpet]</ref> <ref>{{cite book|last=Beattie|first=May H.|title=Carpets of Central Persia: With Special Reference to the Rugs of Kirman|isbn=978-0-905035-17-8|publisher =Al Tajir-World of Islam Trust|year=1976}}</ref>
Modern Kerman rugs, made for western markets, are often woven in gentle and light colors such as amber, pink, and blue-gray. They may employ western patterns, such as stripes and various repetitive motifs, as well as more traditional vase and garden themes, animal shapes, and pictorial designs.
==Technique==
May Beattie has defined seven classes of Kerman carpets and identified a unique structure she called the "Vase technique" characterised by three shoots of [[weft]] between rows of knots.<ref>{{cite book|last=Beattie|first=May H.|title=Carpets of Central Persia: With Special Reference to the Rugs of Kirman|isbn=978-0-905035-17-8|publisher =Al Tajir-World of Islam Trust|year=1976}}</ref> The first and third are typically woolen and at high tension, while the second one, at low tension, is normally made of silk or cotton. [[Warp (weaving)|Warps]] are markedly displaced and the Persian knot is open to the left. This technique distinguishes Kerman carpets from both the Safavid (1501-1722) and subsequent (1722-1834) periods. Most Persian carpets, in contrast, used the "[[Turkish knot]]".<ref name="m336"/>
The dye process for Kerman carpets took place while the wool was still in flock and before spinning, allowing for uniform color. The palette for Kerman carpets is as brilliant as it is varied. Tones can range from ivory, blue and magenta to a more golden and saffron cast.
==History== [[File:Antique Persian Kerman Rug with Allover Pattern.jpg|thumb|left|Antique Persian Kerman Rug]] Kerman has been a major center for the production of high quality carpets since at least the 15th century.
By the 17th century Kerman's designers were at their most inventive and their weaving techniques of a sophistication not seen in other parts of the Persian empire. For instance, the weavers had learned to set their looms so that the cotton warps were on two different levels. They then threaded the wool wefts, leaving some tight and others sinuous, giving an immediately recognisable wavy finish to the surface of the carpet
In the 18th century some authors considered the carpets from the province, especially at Siftan, to be the finest of all Persian carpets,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Beawes|first1=Wyndham|last2=Savary des Brusions|first2=Jacques|title=Lex mercatoria redivida|page=644|publisher=James Williams |year=1773}}</ref> partly because of the high quality of the wool from the region,<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=John|year=1747|title=Chronicon rusticum-commerciale|page=462|publisher=T. Osborne}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Masson de Morvillier|first=Nicolas|year=1784|title=Encyclopédie méthodique: géographie moderne, vol 2|language=French|publisher=Panckouke|page=127}}</ref> known as Carmania wool. [[Nader Shah]], [[Naser al-Din Shah Qajar|Naser al-Din Shah]] commissioned carpets from Kerman.<ref>Maktabi, 337</ref> in the 18th century.
By the 19th century, the city of Kerman had a long history of urban workshops, very fine wool, master weavers and a reputation for the artistic superiority of its designs.<ref name="m336">Maktabi, 336</ref>
==See also== [[Persian carpet]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Maktabi, Hadi. "Under the Peacock Throne; Carpets, Felts and Silks in Persian Painting, 1736-1834", in Muqarnas, Volume 26, BRILL, 2009, {{ISBN|90-04-17589-X}}, 9789004175891, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Gq6obUbnqsMC&pg=PA336&dq=Kirman+carpets&hl=en&ei=UOgTTcD4G86IhQfP9f23Dg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&sqi=2&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Kirman%20carpets&f=false google books] {{refbegin}} * {{Citation | last=Sakhai | first=Essie | title=Persian Rugs and Carpets The Fabric of Life | publisher=Antique Collectors' Club | place=Woodbridge, Suffolk, England | year=2008 | ISBN=978-1-85149-507-8 }} {{refend}}
{{Rugs and carpets}}
[[Category:Persian rugs and carpets]]

<big>'''សមាគមអ្នកនិពន្ធខ្មែរ'''-</big>"'''សអខ"The '''Khmer Writers Association''' ('''KWA''') (alternates: '''Association of Khmer Writers''';<ref>Ollier, p. xv</ref> '''Association des Ecrivains Khmers''';<ref name="Hobbs1960">{{cite book|last=Hobbs|first=Cecil|title=Southeast Asia publication sources: an account of a field trip, 1958-1959|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cqgSAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=15 January 2011|year=1960|publisher=Southeast Asia Program, Dept. of Far Eastern Studies, Cornell University|page=51}}</ref> '''Association of Cambodian Writers'''<ref name="Chee1981">{{cite book|last=Chee|first=Tham Seong|title=Essays on Literature and Society in Southeast Asia: Political and Sociological Perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h6SOvP6FLskC&pg=PA80|accessdate=16 January 2011|year=1981|publisher=NUS Press|isbn=978-9971-69-036-6|pages=80–}}</ref>) was established in 1954<ref name="JarvisAfranis2002" /> or 1956,<ref name="Smyth2000">{{cite book|last=Smyth|first=David|title=The canon in Southeast Asian literatures: literatures of Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2GdP6NNzCMoC&pg=PA144|accessdate=15 January 2011|year=2000|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-7007-1090-4|pages=144–}}</ref> and re-established in 1993 as a [[non-governmental organization]].<ref name="JarvisAfranis2002" /> Previously located at 465 Bd. Preah Monawang,<ref name="Hobbs1960" /> it is currently located at Oknha Suor Srun (St. 7), [[Wat Botum]], [[Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia]].<ref name="tourismcambodia.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.tourismcambodia.com/directory/community/other-organizations/8626_khmer-writers-association.htm|title=Khmer Writers Association|work=tourismcambodia.com|accessdate=15 January 2011}}</ref>
The organization encourages and promotes writing while offering training programs and competitions.<ref name="JarvisAfranis2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.tkgev.org/docs/2002_Publishing_in_Cambodia.pdf |title=Publishing in Cambodia - A Survey and Report |last=Jarvis |first=Helen |author2=Afranis, Peter |date=December 2002 |publisher=Commissioned by the Publishing in Cambodia Project Co-Sponsored by the Center for Khmer Studies, Reyum Institute & the Toyota Foundation |pages=36, 40 |accessdate=15 January 2011 |location=Phnom Penh |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728110829/http://www.tkgev.org/docs/2002_Publishing_in_Cambodia.pdf |archivedate=28 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> Its authors try to promote a new direction to literature, introducing new themes, such as the abandonment of morality incompatible with modern life; developing new genres, such as ''theatre nouveau'';<ref name="Phœun1998">{{cite journal|last=Phœun|first=Mak|year=1998|title=Khing Hoc Dy : Écrivains et expressions littéraires du Cambodge au XXe s. Contribution à l'histoire de la littérature khmère|journal=[[École française d'Extrême-Orient|Bulletin de l'Ecole française d'Extrême-Orient]] (BEFEO)|volume=2|issue=85|page=496|url=http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/befeo_0336-1519_1998_num_85_1_2586|issn=0336-1519|language=French}}</ref> and providing translations, such as ''[[One Thousand and One Nights|The Arabian Nights]]'', as part of a "didactic and diverse" genre.<ref name="Hansen2007" /> According to Smyth, the establishment of the KWA helped complete the "institutionalization of Khmer literature" as, through the 1960s, it became the vehicle for writing and publishing textbooks on [[Literature of Cambodia|Khmer literature]] and [[literary criticism]].<ref name="Smyth2000" /> In the 2000s, the organization's focus has shifted; it provides training programs for writing poetry and film screenplays.<ref name="culturalprofiles.net" />
==History== [[Rim Kin]] (1911–1959), the author of the first modern prose published novel in Cambodia,<ref name="JacobSmyth1993">{{cite book|last1=Jacob|first1=Judith M.|last2=Smyth|first2=David|last3=Studies|first3=University of London. School of Oriental and African|title=Cambodian linguistics, literature and history: collected articles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gQwGbvy5OXcC&pg=PA160|accessdate=16 January 2011|year=1993|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-7286-0218-2|pages=160–}}</ref> was president from 1955 until 1957.<ref name="Huffman1988">{{cite book|last=Huffman|first=Franklin E.|title=Intermediate Cambodian Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Wqc-iIdb_YC&pg=PA336|accessdate=15 January 2011|date=30 July 1988|publisher=SEAP Publications|isbn=978-0-87727-522-0|pages=336, 470}}</ref> Only one of the organization's ten founding members was a woman, [[Suy Hieng]].<ref name="Jacobsen2008">{{cite book|last=Jacobsen|first=Trudy|title=Lost goddesses: the denial of female power in Cambodian history|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-9unZvFaiREC&pg=PA190|accessdate=16 January 2011|year=2008|publisher=NIAS Press|isbn=978-87-7694-001-0|pages=190–}}</ref> Sam Thang and Hell Sumphea served as subsequent presidents.<ref name="Jacobsen2008" /> In the late 1950s, Ly Theam Teng, the association's secretary, established an agreement to send their bi-monthly publication, ''Ecrivains Khmers'' ("Khmer Writers") to the [[Library of Congress]].<ref name="Hobbs1960" />
In 1970, according to its president Trinh Hoanh, there were 178 members representing most of the Cambodian writers.<ref name="Chee1981" /> Hoanh was still president in the mid-1970s.<ref name="Proceedings1976">{{cite journal|year=1976|title=Proceedings|journal=Pacific Northwest Council on Foreign Languages|publisher=Oregon State University|volume=28|issue=2|url=http://www.google.com/search?tbs=bks%3A1&tbo=1&q=akw&btnG=Search+Books#sclient=psy&hl=en&tbo=1&tbs=bks:1&q=The+influence+of+French+literature+on+the+Khmer+writers+was+frankly+admitted+by+Trinh+Hoanh%2C+president+of+the+%22Association+des+ecrivains+khmers.%22+&aq=&aqi=&aql=&oq=&pbx=1&fp=4f42b995651e974b}}</ref> Destroyed under [[Democratic Kampuchea]], the association was re-established in 1993 by two former members, [[You Bo]] and Sou Chamran, with King [[Norodom Sihanouk]] serving as honorary president.<ref name="JarvisAfranis2002" /> Bo served as president from 1994–96, [[Chey Chap]] succeeded him, and Bo became president again in 1998.<ref name="JarvisAfranis2002" />
Starting in 1995, the KWA organised the annual Khmer Literature Festival. It also staged competitions for novel and poetry writing, and gave out two awards: the Preah Sihanouk Reach Award and the 7 January Award. The topic of the PSRA competition was national unification and peace, while the topic of the January competition was national development. Lacking funds, the festival and awards did not continue after 2000.<ref name="culturalprofiles.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.culturalprofiles.net/cambodia/units/182.html|title=Khmer Writers’ Association|date=24 July 2005|work=culturalprofiles.net|accessdate=16 January 2011}}</ref>
As of 2002, there were 192 members with approximately half being professional writers.<ref name="JarvisAfranis2002" />
==Notable people== [[Pal Vannariraks]], a female Cambodian writer of social and sentimental novels, won first prize in the 1989 Seven January literary competition.<ref name="May2004">{{cite journal|last=May|first=Sharon|year=2004|title=Words from the Fire: Three Cambodian Women Writers|journal=Manoa|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|volume=16|issue=1|issn=1045-7909|doi=10.1353/man.2004.0016|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri=/journals/manoa/v016/16.1may05.pdf}}</ref> At a 2009 [[University of Cambodia]] interview with 18-year-old [[Noun Pichsoudeny]], the youngest student writer in the [[Kingdom of Cambodia]] and the author of four published novels, she stated she was a current member of KWA.<ref name="ucfoundation.net">{{cite web|url=http://ucfoundation.net/ucf/?p=80|title=Cambodia's Youngest Writer|date=December 13, 2009|work=ucfoundation.net|publisher=University of Cambodia Foundation|accessdate=15 January 2011}}</ref>
Membership is not limited to residents of Cambodia. [[Nada Marinković]] (1921–1998), a Yugoslavian journalist and author, was a past member.<ref name="arhiv-beograda.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.arhiv-beograda.org/english/legacy_nada.html |title=Legacy of Nada Marinković |work=arhiv-beograda.org |publisher=Historical Archives of Belgrade |accessdate=15 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100922184918/http://arhiv-beograda.org/english/legacy_nada.html |archivedate=22 September 2010 |df= }}</ref> [[Pech Sangwawann]], the short story writer who fled to France and founded the Association des Ecrivains Khmers a l'Etranger ("Association of Khmer Writers Abroad"),<ref name="OllierWinter2006">{{cite book|last1=Ollier|first1=Leakthina Chan-Pech|last2=Winter|first2=Tim|title=Expressions of Cambodia: the politics of tradition, identity, and change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c0z3aP7s4acC&pg=PA154|accessdate=15 January 2011|year=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-38554-1|pages=154–}}</ref> was a long-time member of KWA before 1975.<ref name="EbiharaMortland1994">{{cite book|last1=Ebihara|first1=May|last2=Mortland|first2=Carol Anne|last3=Ledgerwood|first3=Judy|title=Cambodian culture since 1975: homeland and exile|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BDt96S0N65AC&pg=PA29|accessdate=15 January 2011|year=1994|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-8173-4|pages=29–30}}</ref>
==Criticism== A 1966 catalog of KWA works includes the Buddhism genres of [[Paracanonical texts (Theravada Buddhism)|Pali]] and [[Dharma (Buddhism)|Dhamma]]. Some of the works, characterized as being interpretations by "modernist intellectuals", may not represent the view of all [[Buddhism in Cambodia|Khmer Buddhists]].<ref name="Hansen2007">{{cite book|last=Hansen|first=Anne Ruth|title=How to behave: Buddhism and modernity in colonial Cambodia, 1860-1930|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GphGlpBRCVgC&pg=PA222|accessdate=15 January 2011|year=2007|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-3032-8|pages=222–}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}}
[[Category:Cambodian literature]] [[Category:Culture in Phnom Penh]] [[Category:Organisations based in Cambodia]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1956]] [[Category:Writers' organizations by country|Cambodia]]

{{For|the Persian architectural style|Khorasani style}} '''Khorāsānī style''' (Persian: ''sabk-i Khorāsānī'' 'the style of Khurāsān', also known as ''sabk-i Turkistānī'' 'the style of Turkistan', also transliterated ''Khurāsānī'') was a movement in Persian poetry associated with the court of the [[Ghaznavids]], associated with [[Greater Khorasan]] (now divided between Iran, Afghanistan, and Uzbekistan). ==History== The term was coined in the early twentieth century.'Persian Poetry', in ''The Princeton Handbook of World Poetries'', ed. by Roland Greene and Stephen Cushman (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2017), p. 419. It is traditionally considered to characterise the first period of [[New Persian]] poetry, running from the ninth century CE into the second half of the twelfth. It is characterized by its plain poetic technique, concrete images and metaphors, and some archaic linguistic features. While showing limited use of Arabic loan-words, poetry in this style was influenced by Arabic verse, particularly in terms of its prosody, and the dominant genre was the praise-poem.A. A. Seyed-Gohrab, ''Courtly Riddles: Enigmatic Embellishments in Early Persian Poetry'' (Leiden: Leiden University Press, 2010), p. 20; Angela Sadeghi Tehrani, 'Modernist Poetry in Iran and the Pioneers', ''Asian Journal of Multidisciplinary Studies'', 2.7 (July 2014), 167-69 (p. 167). The Khurāsānī period was succeeded by the ''[[sabk-i ‘Irāqī]]'' ('style of Iraq'), with its greater use of Arabisms, more elaborate metaphors and imagery, and turn towards spiritualism.A. A. Seyed-Gohrab, ''Courtly Riddles: Enigmatic Embellishments in Early Persian Poetry'' (Leiden: Leiden University Press, 2010), p. 20. However, the transition between the periods was not a sharp one.Asghar Seyed-Gohrab, 'Stylistic Continuities in Classical Persian Poetry: Reflections on Manuchehri from Dāmghān and Amir Mo‘ezzi', in ''The Age of the Seljuqs, ed. by Edmund Herzig and Sarah Stewart, The Idea of Iran, 6 (I. B. Tauris). The style saw a return to popularity with the so-called literary revival (''bazgasht-e abadi'') of the eighteenth to twentieth centuries.Angela Sadeghi Tehrani, 'Modernist Poetry in Iran and the Pioneers', ''Asian Journal of Multidisciplinary Studies'', 2.7 (July 2014), 167-69 (p. 168). ==Exponents== The pre-eminent study of the style was by Muḥammad Jaʻfar Maḥjūb in 1971.''Sabk-i Khurāsānī dar shiʻr-i Fārsī : barrasī-i mukhtaṣṣāt-i sabkī-i shiʻr-i Fārsī az āghāz-i ẓuhūr tā pāyān-i qarn-i panjum hijrī'' [The Khorasani style in Persian poetry: studies of the stylistic character of Persian poetry from its origins to the end of the fifth century of the Hegira] ([Tihrān]: Intishārāt-i Firdaws, 199-? [first publ. 1971]). The chief representatives of this lyricism are [[Asjadi]], [[Farrukhi Sistani]], [[Unsuri]], and [[Manuchihri|Manuchehri]]. Panegyric masters such as [[Rudaki]] were known for their love of nature, their verse abounding with evocative descriptions. ==Example== A. A. Seyed-Gohrab contrasts the following passages to illustrate the Khorāsānī style.A. A. Seyed-Gohrab, ''Courtly Riddles: Enigmatic Embellishments in Early Persian Poetry'' (Leiden: Leiden University Press, 2010), pp. 39-42, drawing on Julie Scott Meisami, 'Palaces and Paradises: Palace Description in Medieval Persian Poetry', in ''Islamic Art and Literature'', ed. by O. Grabar and C. Robinson (Princeton, 2001), pp. 21-54. The first is a description of a palace from ''Qaṣīda 31'' by Farrukhī Sistānī, writing in the earlier eleventh century. It is plain and concrete in its description:
: There was a kingly palace in the middle of the garden : The top of the parapets was situated between two turrets : Within the palace, there were decorated porticoes : Each opening towards a belvedere : One was adorned like Chinese brocade : The other contained pictures as in Mani's ''Artang'' : In this palace, the images of the King of the East : Were carved/painted in several places: : In one place, he is fighting, holding in his hand a small javelin : In another place, he is feasting, holding in his hand a cup of wine.
The second is from the end of the ''sabk-i Khurāsānī'' period, near to the ''sabk-i ‘Irāqī'' period: a description of a palace built by [[Arslan-Shah of Ghazna|Arslān Shah of Ghazna]], composed by [[‘Uthmān Mukhtārī]] in the vicinity of 1100. This description is far less concrete and much more spiritual in tone:
: The ancient sphere established the centre of the world's empire : Through this place, through which Jupiter exercises its heavenly influence. : When the sun saw its parapets from the sky, : It bowed its head to the ground, and its eyes to the threshold. : [When] the virgins of paradise beheld it from their gardens, : They took this palace for gold, and paradise as the mine. : They considered the earth insignificant because of its firm structure; : The air in this palace was so fine that the air (outside) was heavy. : The architect used his intellect and soul to design this edifice : Through the firmness of his intellect and the grace of his soul.
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Persian literature]] [[Category:History of literature]] [[Category:Persian-language literature]] [[Category:Arts in Iran]]

revision.text:
{{italictitle}} A '''''Künstlerroman''''' ({{IPA-de|ˈkʏnstlɐ.ʁoˌmaːn}}; plural -ane), meaning "artist's novel" in English, is a [[narrative]] about an artist's growth to maturity.<ref name="Werlock2010p387">Werlock, James P. (2010) [https://books.google.com/books?id=lWuyTK_0eBsC&pg=PA387 The Facts on File companion to the American short story], Volume 2, p.387</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bflZc3a6mxMC&pg=PA13&dq=Künstlerroman+definition&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SRYKUpPWD-bkyQH51oHADQ&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Künstlerroman%20definition&f=false A Studio of One's Own: Fictional Women Painters and the Art of Fiction] by Roberta White (page 13) published 2005 by Rosemont Publishing & Printing Crops. Accessed Via Google Books August 13, 2013.</ref>
It may be classified as a specific subgenre of ''[[Bildungsroman]]'';<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=MN4ZRn3D5PsC&pg=PA128&dq=Künstlerroman+definition&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SRYKUpPWD-bkyQH51oHADQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwCg#v=onepage&q=Künstlerroman%20definition&f=false Germaine de Staël in Germany: Gender and Literary Authority] by Judith E. Martin (page 128) 2001 Fairleigh & Dickinson University Press</ref> such a work, usually a novel, tends to depict the conflicts of a sensitive youth against the values of a middle and upper class society of his or her time.
==Examples== ;In German *[[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]]'s 1795 ''[[Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship]]'' *[[Ludwig Tieck]]'s 1798 ''[[Franz Sternbalds Wanderungen]]'' *[[Novalis]]'s 1802 ''[[Heinrich von Ofterdingen]]'' *[[Hermann Hesse]]'s ''[[Demian]]'' (1919) and ''[[Klingsor's Last Summer]]'' (1920) *[[Thomas Mann]]'s ''[[Tonio Kröger]]'' (1903), and ''[[Doctor Faustus (novel)|Doctor Faustus]]'' (1947) *[[Jakob Wassermann]]'s 1915 ''[[Das Gänsemännchen]]'' *[[Rainer Maria Rilke]]'s 1910 ''[[The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge]]''
; In English {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *1805 [[William Wordsworth]]'s ''[[The Prelude]]'' *1847 [[Charlotte Brontë]]'s ''[[Jane Eyre]]'' *1848 [[Anne Brontë]]'s ''[[The Tenant of Wildfell Hall]]'' *1850 [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[David Copperfield]]'' *1852 [[Herman Melville]]'s ''[[Pierre: or, The Ambiguities]]'' *1856 [[Elizabeth Barrett Browning]]'s ''[[Aurora Leigh]]'' *1875 [[Henry James]]'s ''[[Roderick Hudson]]'' *1890 [[Henry James]]'s ''[[The Tragic Muse]]'' *1903 [[Samuel Butler (novelist)|Samuel Butler]]'s ''[[The Way of All Flesh]]'' *1909 [[Jack London]] ''[[Martin Eden]]'' *1913 [[D. H. Lawrence]]'s ''[[Sons and Lovers]]'' *1915 [[W. Somerset Maugham]]'s ''[[Of Human Bondage]]'' *1915 [[Willa Cather]]'s ''[[The Song of the Lark]]'' *1916 [[James Joyce]]'s ''[[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]''<ref name="Werlock2010p387"/> *1918 [[Wyndham Lewis]]'s ''[[Tarr]]'' *1920 [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]]'s ''[[This Side of Paradise]]'' *1928 [[Radclyffe Hall]]'s ''[[The Well of Loneliness]]'' *1929 [[Thomas Wolfe]]'s ''[[Look Homeward, Angel]]'' *1933 [[Malcolm Lowry]]'s [[Ultramarine (novel)|''Ultramarine'']] *1936 [[George Orwell]]'s ''[[Keep the Aspidistra Flying]]'' *1939 [[John Fante]]'s ''[[Ask the Dust]]'' *1945 [[Richard Wright (author)|Richard Wright]]'s ''[[Black Boy]]'' *1947 [[W. O. Mitchell|W.O. Mitchell]]'s ''[[W. O. Mitchell#Quotation|Who Has Seen the Wind]]'' *1952 [[Patricia Highsmith]]'s ''[[The Price of Salt]]'' *1955 [[William Gaddis]]'s ''[[The Recognitions]]'' *1961 [[Irving Stone]]'s ''[[The Agony and the Ecstasy (novel)|The Agony and the Ecstasy]]'' *1970 [[Patrick White]]'s ''[[The Vivisector]]'' *1971 [[Alice Munro]]'s ''[[Lives of Girls and Women]]'' *1972 [[Chaim Potok]]'s ''[[My Name Is Asher Lev]]'' *1973 [[Milan Kundera]]'s ''[[Life Is Elsewhere]]'' *1974 [[Margaret Laurence]]'s ''[[The Diviners]]'' *1978 [[John Irving]]'s ''[[The World According to Garp]]'' *1981 [[Alasdair Gray]]'s ''[[Lanark: A Life in Four Books]]'' *1982 [[Charles Bukowski]]'s ''[[Ham on Rye]]''<ref>[[David Stephen Calonne|Calonne, David Stephen]]. Charles Bukowski. Reaktion Books, London, 2012. p. 146. {{ISBN|978-1-78023-023-8}}</ref> *1988 [[Margaret Atwood]]'s ''[[Cat's Eye (novel)|Cat's Eye]]'' *1999 [[Tracy Chevalier]]'s ''[[Girl with a Pearl Earring (novel)|Girl with a Pearl Earring]]''<ref>Miriam de Paiva Vieira, "From Canvas to Paper: The Novel by Tracy Chevalier", [http://www.bibliotecadigital.ufmg.br/dspace/bitstream/handle/1843/ECAP-7A3H7K/dissertacao_mestrado_miriam_vieira.pdf?sequence=1 ''Art and New Media: Vermeer’s Work under Different Semiotic Systems''] p.19</ref> *2003 [[Jennifer Donnelly]]'s ''[[A Northern Light]]'' *2006 [[Alison Bechdel]]'s ''[[Fun Home]]'' *2006 [[Stew (musician)|Stew]]'s ''[[Passing Strange]]'' *2010 [[Eileen Myles]]'s ''Inferno (A Poet's Novel)'' *2010 [[Wena Poon]]'s ''Alex y Robert'', the Asian American ''Künstlerroman'' {{div col end}}
[[Alasdair Gray]]'s ''[[Lanark: A Life in Four Books]]'' consists of four books arranged in the order 3, 1, 2, 4; books 1 and 2 constituting a ''Künstlerroman''. In [[John Dos Passos]]' [[U.S.A. trilogy]], the ''Camera Eye'' sections add up to a [[modernism|modernist]] [[autobiography|autobiographical]] ''Künstlerroman''. [[John Barth]]'s ''[[Lost in the Funhouse]]'' is a collection of short stories that are often read as a [[postmodernism|postmodernist]] ''Künstlerroman''.
; In French *1831, 1837 [[Honore de Balzac]]'s ''[[The Unknown Masterpiece]]'' *1904–1905 [[Romain Rolland]]'s ''[[Jean-Christophe]]'' *1913- 1927 [[Marcel Proust]]'s ''[[In Search of Lost Time]]''<ref>John Neary [https://books.google.com/books?id=CpOa5vsGx34C&pg=PA54 ''Something and nothingness: the fiction of John Updike & John Fowles''] p.54</ref><ref>Gilles Deleuze. ''Marcel Proust et les signes''. Paris: PUF, 1964]</ref>

[[Renaissance Pictures]]
[[Universal Television]] | distributor = [[NBCUniversal Television Distribution]] | channel = [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = {{start date|1994|08|26}} | last_aired = {{end date|1995|03|3}} }} '''''M.A.N.T.I.S.''''' is an American [[science fiction]] television series that aired for one season on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Network]] between August 26, 1994 and March 3, 1995. The original two-hour [[television pilot|pilot]] was produced by [[Sam Raimi]] and developed by [[Sam Hamm]]. ==Plot== A wealthy, mild-mannered doctor, Miles Hawkins, is shot in the spine during a riot, leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. After losing a lawsuit against a police officer he holds responsible, he uses his company's resources to invent a [[powered exoskeleton]] that not only enables him to walk but gives him superhuman abilities in the process. Using a vast array of technology, including a large underwater lab and a [[hovercraft]] called the ''Crysalid'' to fly around the city, he assumes the persona of the vigilante "M.A.N.T.I.S." (Mechanically Augmented Neuro Transmitter Interception System). The pilot featured [[Gina Torres]] as pathologist Dr. Amy Ellis, [[Bobby Hosea]] as reporter Yuri Barnes, and [[Wendy Raquel Robinson]] and [[Chris M. Brown (actor)|Christopher M. Brown]] as a pair of African students studying under Hawkins. In the series, the supporting cast was changed to John Stonebrake, Taylor Savage and Lt. Maxwell, with the plot being completely rebooted.{{cite news|title= 'M.A.N.T.I.S.' Undergoes Pilot-to-Series Changes : New Producers of TV Series About an African American Super-Hero Cite Creative Reasons; Others Claim Racism |publisher= [[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=1994-08-25|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1994-08-25/entertainment/ca-31151_1_series-pilot|accessdate=2011-01-14|first=Greg|last=Braxton}} The bulk of the series' run depicted the M.A.N.T.I.S. operating in a vigilante role, frequently pursued by police, and battling industrialist Solomon Box ([[Brion James]] / [[Andrew Robinson (actor)|Andrew J. Robinson]]).{{cite news|title= TV REVIEWS : 'Mantis' a Super-Hero Without a Prayer |publisher= [[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=1994-01-24|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1994-01-24/entertainment/ca-14729_1_mantis-ii|accessdate=2011-01-14|first=Howard|last=Rosenberg}} In the series' final installment, Miles Hawkins and Lt. Maxwell are killed disposing of an invisible prehistoric dinosaur. John Stonebrake seals off the records and technology that had created the M.A.N.T.I.S., thus averting an apocalyptic future. While the title character's death was given a sense of finality, the story was left open in one respect: when Miles Hawkins returned to 1994 from the year 2026 (a 32-year difference), he did so precisely 32 seconds after his vehicle sent him forward in time, thus altering the computer-controlled future that his disappearance had led to. As such, Miles Hawkins, while dying in the reality that he returned to, was also sent forward in time to an unknown future, leaving his actual fate ambiguous. ==Cast== * [[Carl Lumbly]] – Dr. Miles Hawkins (22 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Roger Rees]] – John Stonebrake (22 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Christopher Gartin]] – Taylor Savage (22 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Galyn Görg]] – Lt. Maxwell (22 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Gary Graham]] – Capt. Ken Hetrick (9 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Jerry Wasserman]] – Det. Paul Warren (6 episodes, 1994) * [[Garry Chalk (actor)|Garry Chalk]] – Detective Reid (4 episodes, 1994–1995) * Blu Mankuma – Chief Grant (4 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Clabe Hartley]] – Tony (4 episodes, 1994) * [[Robert Hooks]] – Mayor Lew Mitchell (3 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Andrew Kavadas]] – MIB #2 / ... (3 episodes, 1994–1995) * [[Martin Cummins]] – Paul Benton / ... (3 episodes, 1994) * [[Peter Brost]] – Young Dr. Miles Hawkins (3 episodes, 1994–1995) ==Production== The series was produced in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada. Many Vancouver landmarks, such as the dome of Science World, appear. It took three years to film due to Carl Lumbly being busy filming ''[[Nightjohn (film)|Nightjohn]]''. There were a number of differences between the pilot and the series. For example, in the pilot, Hawkins wore a suit over the exo-skeleton, it lacked a skullcap, and the headpiece was larger. The setting was changed from Oceania City to Port Columbia, and all of the characters, with Hawkins being an exception, were changed. Poor ratings led to an extensive retooling of the concept. Midway through the show's run, minor characters were jettisoned, and more fantasy adventure elements were incorporated into the premise, including [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universes]], [[time travel]], super-villains, and monsters. In one particular episode, the M.A.N.T.I.S. is accidentally thrown 32 years into the future, where he finds that his own technology has been exploited to create a supercomputer that is being used to enslave the Port Columbia population. He destroys it and sets the human population free before returning to his own time. ==Episodes== {{Episode table |background=#aabbff|overall=5 |title=30 |director=15 |writer=35 |airdate=10 |prodcode=5 country=U.S. |episodes= {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = First Steps | DirectedBy = [[David Nutter]] | WrittenBy = [[Bryce Zabel]] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1994|8|26}} | ProdCode = 69601 | ShortSummary = In the series opener, Miles puts his exoskeleton to use to foil the plans of Solomon Box. | LineColor = aabbff }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | Title = Tango Blue | DirectedBy = [[Joe Napolitano]] | WrittenBy = [[Paris Qualles]] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1994|9|2}} | ProdCode = 69602 | ShortSummary = | LineColor = aabbff }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | Title = Days of Rage | DirectedBy = [[Les Landau]] | WrittenBy = {{StoryTeleplay|s=Bryce Zabel & John M.
